items.item_details: Education Code Section 72122 provides that student disciplinary matters be considered by the Board of Trustees in closed session unless the student submits a written request to the Board Secretary that the hearing of the governing board be held as a public meeting.  As of the time of posting the agenda, no such request had been received; however, the deadline for submission of the request had not yet passed.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District was successful at the election on June 6, 2006, in obtaining authorization from the District's voters to issue up to $490,800,000 aggregate principal amount of the District's general obligation bonds (“Measure C”). The election was conducted under Proposition 39, which was chaptered as the Strict Accountability in Local School Construction Bonds Act of 2000. Among the accountability requirements the District must comply with is the establishment of a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee whose duties and responsibilities are set forth in bylaws as shown on the Measure C website at http://www.measurec.fhda.edu/. The duties include the development of an Annual Report which shall be presented to the Board of Trustees in public session. The report is required to address the following:
A statement indicating whether the District is in compliance with the requirements of Article XIIIA, Section 1(b)(3) of the California Constitution; and,
A summary of the Committee’s proceedings and activities for the preceding year.
The annual report for 2014/2015 will be presented by Mr. Dudley Andersen, Chairperson of the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee, and can be viewed at http://measurec.fhda.edu/AR1415/printfriendly.pdf
	 
Submitted by:
 Steven Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities & Operations, x6150
Additional contact names:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director of Facilities and Operations Steven Kitchen recommends that the Board accept the report.

*Advancement in the tenure process is contingent upon having met all requirements including having served a complete probationary contract year. A probationary faculty employee is deemed to have completed a probationary contract year if he or she provides service for 75 percent of the academic year. If the probationary faculty employee serves less than 75 percent of an academic year, the year shall be considered a âprob zeroâ year and shall not count for tenure. In such cases the tenure process is interrupted by the prob zero year and shall be resumed in the subsequent academic year in which the faculty employee is able to perform services for 75 percent of the academic year.

  Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity, x6211

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Student Success Center continues to offer and promote wrap-around academic support services to students, usage of ST online usage has steadily increased.  To continue providing uninterrupted online tutoring services to our students for the Winter and Spring 2016 quarters, we are requesting that the Board of Trustees approve the additional $45,000 purchase of 1800 ST hours at $25 per hour, bringing the original contract of $79,994 to a total of $124,994.  
	 
Below is the data comparing 2014 quarters to their relative 2015 quarters for ST online tutoring services.
	 
Quarter          Users    % Change       Sessions   % Change        Time (hr)  % Change
Spring 14         387                                1102                                    639.2
Spring 15         439         +13%             1391             +26%              909.5            +42%
	 
Summer 14      135                                 349                                      221.8
Summer 15      195         +44%              527               +51%              332.8           +50%
	 
Fall 14             475                                1606                                     990.4
Fall 15             591         +24%             1764               +10%            1164.0          +18%
	 
Winter 15*      510                                1729                                     1135.7
  * Note: Winter 15 is the only Winter quarter that  ST services have been available.
	 
The SSC is among the largest community college academic support programs in the state. We provide academic and instructional support to De Anza College students and faculty in five SSC centers:  
Academic Skills Center (ATC 303)
Listening & Speaking Center (ATC 313)
General Subject Tutoring (ATC 304)
Math, Science & Technology Resource Center (S43)
Writing & Reading Center (ATC 309)
	 
	 
Services Offered
Drop-in tutoring
Group tutoring
In-class tutoring
Weekly individual tutoring
Online tutoring via Smarthinking
Workshops for content, study skills, listening enhancement 
260+ unique student tutors training, mentoring, supervision, and employment during the 2014-15 academic year.
Annual Usage
10,000+ unique students participated in one or more SSC program offerings
80,000+ student hours of drop-in, group, weekly individual tutoring and workshops
225+ in-class interventions (in-class and lab tutoring) supported thousands of students
1500+ group tutoring sessions and workshops
100+ instructors coordinate their instruction with the SSC via office hours, in-class tutoring, adjunct skills courses, or workshops per quarter
Online tutoring had 1332 distinct users with 5100 total sessions for 3272 hours.
Submitted by:
De Anza College President Brian Murphy, ext. 8705
Additional contact names:
Lorrie Ranck, Dean Learning Resources x8489. Melissa Aguilar, Co Director x5422
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
1) New Student and Parent Open House
This major annual event welcomes prospective new students and their families to the college to engage with numerous faculty and staff representatives, tour the campus and take placement tests. This year, students will be provided opportunities to fulfill priority enrollment criteria through not only taking placement tests but also completing orientation. The Open House will be held from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. in the Sunken Garden.
	 
2) Auto Technology Club Car Show
Since 2014, the De Anza Automotive Technology Club has held an annual car show fundraiser. The event was held previously at Canepa Design-a-world-class auto restoration shop in Scotts Valley.  The event was an unequivocal success and the club would like to start a new tradition by hosting the event at De Anza College. The event will be held from 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. Parking Lot E. 
	 
3) Coast Conference Track and Field event
The Coast Conference Track and Field Championships event is scheduled for Saturday, April 30 beginning at 10:00 a.m. It is our Conference Championships and the first time De Anza will host the event. We anticipate 300 competitors with 8 athletic teams, not including coaches, officials and fans. Parking Lot C, Stelling Parking structure and Parking Lot D are requested from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 pm (for set up and tear down).
	 
Submitted by:
 De Anza College President Brian Murphy, ext 8705
Additional contact names:
 Rob Mieso, AVP, Student Services, ext 8835
 Randy Bryant, Automotive Technology, ext 8840
 Coleen Lee-Wheat, Physical Education & Athletics, ext 8402
Is backup provided?
 No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for curriculum additions and changes for the 2016-17 Catalog. Per Title 5 direction, all course changes, substantial and non-substantial, must be approved by the governing board of the District before they may be submitted to the State Chancellor's Office for final approval.
	 
These courses have met Foothill’s curriculum standards and the Foothill College Curriculum Committee certifies that they are compliant with Title 5 regulations.

Kurt Hueg, Foothill College Acting Vice President, Instruction

Andrew LaManque, Isaac Escoto

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Foothill College Planning and Resource Council (PaRC) approved the Foothill College Sunnyvale Center Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) Substantive Change Request on March 2, 2016.  
	 
Foothill College is requesting from ACCJC continued accreditation status for the relocation of its established educational center from its current location in Palo Alto to a site in nearby Sunnyvale, with operations beginning at the new location in the fall quarter of 2016.  This change of address will allow the center to serve students in a modern facility owned by the district.
	 
The substantive change request follows the ACCJC format necessary to provide evidence that the Eligibility Requirements, Accreditation Standards, and Commission Policies will still be met.  The request outlines the planning that led to the change, evidence of institutional capacity – Student Services, Staffing, Facilities, Technology and an analysis of the fiscal impact of the change.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Foothill College Interim President
Additional contact names:
Kurt Hueg, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College administration recommends approval of the accreditation substantive change request.

items.item_text_raw: 13. Foothill College Sunnyvale Center Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) Substantive Change Request

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Celebrity Forum Speaker Series has been a part of Foothill College for 48 years. The series is an important community event and draws thousands of people each year to Flint Center. From its founding in 1968, the series has been completely self-supporting and has never used District or college funds for its operation, being financed solely through ticket sales. The series has always been a financial success and has contributed valuable discretionary dollars to Foothill College.
	 
The Foothill College Celebrity Forum has secured January 19, 20, 2017, for performance by Jay Leno through his representative at Gotham Artists. The agreed upon fees for the two appearances is $180,000. Half of this fee will be used as a deposit to lock in Jay Leno’s appearances and is due immediately.  The remaining half will be due before his actual appearances in January 2017.
	 
This item is being submitted to the board for contract approval.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Interim President Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Richard Henning
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College administration recommends approval of the independent contractor agreement with Gotham Artists.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Currently, the District, when contracting for public works construction, is subject to Public Contract Code 20651, which states that “The Governing Board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the Board requires, or else reject all bids.” This dollar limit has not been increased since the law was enacted in 1982 and causes significant challenges to the District for several reasons:
The bid threshold of $15,000 is so low that it limits the ability of the facilities department to contract for minor work on campus in a timely manner.
On many smaller projects, it is unknown whether the project will exceed the bid threshold; therefore, many times the District does not know until quotes come in whether the project requires formal bidding.
Projects that are formally bid require that a detailed specification be written. This adds significant cost and time to smaller and simple projects with no increased benefit to the District.
The bid process for small projects, including architectural drawings, for formal bids can take up to six months. 
The Board of Trustees meets once per month; therefore, work on smaller public works projects is delayed waiting for Board approval. This impacts projects with tight schedules related to work that must be performed during breaks.
There is a provision of Public Contract Code (Section 22000 et seq.) that allows a public agency to adopt the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA), enabling the District to increase the formal bid limits from $15,000 to $175,000, and create informal bidding procedures for projects from $45,000-$175,000.
	 
If CUPCCAA is approved, public works projects will be administered as follows:
	 
Project Value
Delivery Method 
Comments 
$0-$45,000
No formal bid
Exempt from bidding requirements; these projects will be performed by negotiated contract, purchase order, or by our own forces. 
$45,000-$175,000
Informal bidding procedures
Let contract to the qualified contractor submitting the lowest quote through an informal bidding process. The District would still reserve the right to formally bid a project in this range if desired. Bid bonds, performance bonds, and payment bonds would continue to be required of all contractors doing work under these provisions.
Over $175,000
Formal bid 
No substantial change from current bidding requirements.
	 
As part of adopting CUPCCAA, the District would be required to maintain a list of qualified contractors according to the categories of work. The District is required to do contractor outreach on an annual basis and maintain the list. Contractors would be added to the list as requested during the course of the year. All qualified contractors from this list would be solicited on each informal bid between $45,000 and $175,000.
	 
Adopting this section of Public Contract Code will enable the District to more efficiently and effectively manage small to medium sized projects. There are currently 995 California government agencies that have implemented CUPCCAA of which 42 are community college districts such as, Cabrillo, Chabot-Las Positas, Contra Costa, San Mateo, and West Valley-Mission. A complete list can be found here, along with a comprehensive FAQ document prepared by the California State Controller’s Office.   
	 
The Director of Purchasing Services will work with all stakeholders necessary to create informal bidding procedures to include a competitive component that aligns with current Administrative Procedures. The Vice Chancellor of Business Services, Executive Director of Fiscal Services, Executive Director of Facilities & Operations, and District legal counsel have been involved in this process and will continue to be involved until fully implemented. Once implemented, the District may, at any time, revert back to Public Contract Code 20651 by notifying the California State Controller's Office. 
	 
The Board of Trustees must adopt two resolutions to authorize the District to implement this higher bid threshold process. The purpose of this Board Information item is to provide the Trustees with advance background information about the CUPCCAA procedure. The appropriate resolutions will be included on the next regularly scheduled Board meeting agenda with a recommendation for approval.
	 
Submitted by:
 Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6201
 Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities & Operations, x6150
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_text: Information Regarding the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) (INFORMATION)
items.item_text_raw: 20. Information Regarding the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) (INFORMATION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As part of the FY 16 budget, the Governor proposed and the Legislature approved an ongoing allocations of $10 million for the California Community Colleges to conduct the Online Education Initiative (OEI). The California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) awarded these funds through a competitive application process to the Foothill-De Anza Community College District through Request for Application #13-082.  On November 12, 2013, the CCC Board of Governors confirmed this award.  Funding for the OEI Grant Year 1 became available December 1, 2013, and activities related to the project are underway.
	 
FHDA serves as the lead agency and fiscal agent for the OEI grant.  Other agencies and districts are partnering with FHDA to provide various components of the grant as detailed in the FHDA response to RFA #13-082 and approved by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office.  The Southern California Telecommunications and Technology Infrastructure Program (TTIP-South), a program of the Palomar Community College District, is a secondary partner on the OEI grant and is responsible for the following component:
	 
The Online Education Initiative professional development program.  All services necessary to conduct the CCC Online Educator Training and Support Program will be provided through the @One Program currently operated by the TTIP-South program.
	 
In order to accomplish the objective listed above, FHDA will provide the Palomar Community District with $1,430,000 from OEI ongoing and carry-over funds.
	 
Submitted by:
 Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor, Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor Joe Moreau recommends the approval of the following Online Education Initiative Subaward Agreement for Palomar Community College District.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
 
On January 21, 2016, the District posted Request for Qualifications #1750 for Construction Monitoring Services for Smaller Projects on the FHDA portal of the PlanetBids website. Responses were received on February 17, 2016.   The RFQ sought services related to construction monitoring and management of small projects, supporting District staff project managers.  Most projects will be less than $1,000,000 in construction cost and will generally include building repairs or renovations, equipment replacement, scheduled maintenance, temporary facilities, modular furniture installations and accessibility and site projects. The District may also opt to select one of these firms for large capital projects as necessary. Project locations will vary in location and funding source. 
	 
Four firms responded to the Request for Qualifications: 
          Allana Buick & Bers 
          Gilbane 
          SGI Construction Management
          Quali-Con Enterprise, Inc.
	 
District facilities staff reviewed the responses of each applicant and determined that all four firms demonstrated the necessary experience and qualifications to provide services desired by the District.  Firms from this pool will be selected for individual projects based on their experience and qualifications specific to the project, project needs, staff availability and cost effectiveness. Additionally, each of the firms have demonstrated the ability to manage larger projects and the District may also opt to select one of these firms for larger capital projects as necessary.  Firms may be selected from this pool for up to five years from the Board’s acceptance of the pool.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College & District - X6150
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College  - X8289
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Steve Kitchen, Executive Director of Facilities and Operations, recommends that the Board of Trustees accept the list of four firms to be included in a Construction Monitoring Pool and authorize the Executive Director to negotiate contracts for services on an as-needed basis.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Parcel C at the former Onizuka Air Force Station in Sunnyvale, California, was conveyed to Foothill-De Anza Community College District through a Public Benefit Allowance on February 14, 2013.  As required by the deed that conveyed the property, the District prepares an annual utilization report for the U. S. Department of Education to demonstrate that the property is being used solely for uses set forth and approved in the terms and conditions of the deed.  
	 
A copy of the report is provided to the Board of Trustees for information.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College & District x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_text: Annual utilization report for the Foothill-De Anza Education Center at the former Onizuka Air Force Station (INFORMATION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill and De Anza College.  
	 
De Anza Budget Transfer #54 includes the following actions:
Transfer savings of $175,000 from Project 711, Desktops to Project 713, Refresh Multi Media Rooms to add funds to the project. 
Transfer savings of $1,325,000 from Project 712, Printers to Project 713, Refresh Multi Media Rooms to add funds to the project.
Foothill Budget Transfer #56 includes the following actions:
Transfer project savings in the amount of $1,219.86 from Project 115, Fine Art Scene Shop to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms to add funds to the project. Project 115 is financially complete.
Transfer project savings in the amount of $14,031.68 from Project 120, Smithwick Theater to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms to add funds to the project. Project 120 is financially complete.
Note that $142,455.14 from PG&E Rebates for Q1 and Q2 FY1516 will be recognized by Project 199, Foothill Contingency under the category of Other Funding Sources:  Non-state Grant not shown here.
Note that the original allocation of FY 15-16 State Block Grant (Scheduled Maintenance) funding previously reported to the Board on February 8, 2016, in the amount of $355,169, and as recognized by project 141, Exterior Painting and Bird Remediation is changed by Revision #2 to FY 15-16 State Block Grant (Scheduled Maintenance) dated 2/17/2016 to $295,169.
Note that the original allocation of FY 15-16 State Block Grant (Scheduled Maintenance) funding previously reported to the Board on February 8, 2016, in the amount of $375,000, and as recognized by project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms is changed by Revision #2 to FY 15-16 State Block Grant (Scheduled Maintenance) dated 2/17/2016 to $435,000.
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Art Heinrich, Tom Armstrong, Susan Cheu and Donna Jones-Dulin
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Steve Kitchen, Executive Director of Facilities and Operations, recommends that the Board approve the Bond Project List Revision with Foothill Budget Transfer #56 and De Anza Budget Transfer #54.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District’s current telephone system is 15 years old with one available support vendor and the frequency of system problems is increasing.  This current telephone system can only provide basic telephone service.  The District will benefit from a new modern system with collaboration features such as instant messaging and 1-1 desktop video conferencing, receive voice messages attached to email, mobility features with call hand-over between desktop and mobile phones, and a flexible automated attendant system to better serve students.  The new telephone system will allow for emergency alerting through the telephones, specifically in classrooms.
	 
Education Code section 81645 provides that the governing board of any community college district may contract with a party who has submitted one of the three lowest responsible competitive proposals or competitive bids for the acquisition, procurement, or maintenance of electronic data processing systems and equipment, electronic telecommunications equipment, supporting software, and related materials, goods, and services, in accordance with procedures and criteria established by the governing board.
	 
ETS worked with an independent technology consulting company, Communication-Strategies to identify mandatory requirements for the equipment that would meet the current and future needs of the District.  The evaluation committee included representatives from ETS, Purchasing Services, Communication-Strategies, and user groups from both campuses. 
	 
The RFP was legally advertised in the San Jose Post Record on Oct. 8 and Oct. 14, 2015 and the RFP was broadcasted to 250 vendors through purchasing’s web portal.  Proposals were received on Dec. 10, 2015 at 4:00 PM.  Ten vendors submitted proposals, and the results are listed below:
	 
Vendor
Purchase Price
Total Cost of Ownership (purchase price + years 2-5 of maintenance and support)

AMS.NET, Inc.

$1,727,542

Kelso Communications, Inc
non-responsive
non-responsive
					 
	 
After an initial screening to determine responsiveness, the Evaluation Committee shortlisted vendors for further evaluation using the criteria below.  Demonstrations were conducted with the highest ranking and lowest cost proposers as part of the final selection process. 
RFP Responsiveness: A complete response to the RFP that complies with the RFP requirements. A concise response that draws exact parallels to FHDA’s needs with a minimum use of boilerplate marketing material or overly technical language.
Reliability: A system that has a proven track record of reliability as well as an architecture that is inherently fault tolerant.   
Functionality: The ability for the system to improve how FHDA conducts its mission.  The efficiency and effectiveness of communications between all faculty, students, and staff at FHDA is critical to its long term success.
Cost Effectiveness: A cost effective solution in the initial purchase, as well as the ongoing maintenance and servicing of the system. What is deemed the best value.
Manufacturer Vision and Stability: Provider’s commitment to excellence in telecommunications equipment, financial stability, market share, and technological vision for the future.  
Vendor Experience: Evaluation of the Vendor's experience in the design and implementation of similar telecommunications systems and technologies, and Vendor reputation. Evaluation of Vendor’s ability to provide a structured, organized implementation that meets FHDA’s requirements.
Warranty/Maintenance Support: Ability to provide timely support during the installation, warranty period, and ongoing maintenance.  
ETS and Purchasing Services have determined that AMS.NET Incorporated’s proposal is the best value to the District. The AMS.NET, Inc. bid proposal meets all the RFP #1737 mandatory requirements. AMS.NET, Inc. has completed similar projects for other agencies including West Hills Community College District, and Judicial Council of California.
	 
The selected vendor will provide new telecommunications equipment, hardware and software, including necessary accessories and services, in the quantities that comply with the RFP document, subject to modification based upon the final design.   All pricing is turnkey and includes discovery, design, implementation, integration, testing, training, hardware and software. 
	 
The purchase price will be funded with Measure C Phone Equipment project #301 which includes hardware, software, installation labor, and year one-maintenance and support.  Years 2-5 of maintenance and support will be paid from Operational A-Budget funds.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Joe Moreau, Sharon Luciw, Lisa Hocevar, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to execute an agreement with AMS.NET, Inc. in accordance with RFP #1737 District-Wide Unified Communications Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) Platform prices, terms, and conditions for a two-year term with an option to renew up to eight additional one-year terms.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Request for Proposals (RFP) #1737, District-Wide Unified Communications Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) Platform (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The existing roofing system is approximately 20 years old and in need of replacement. This project includes removal of the existing built up roof assembly including shakes, flashing, gutter and underlayment at Building 5400 and replace with new polyurethane coating system, flashing, gutter, and wood shakes. 
	 
Allana Buick & Bers Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1749-105 was legally advertised in the San Jose Post Record on December 22 and December 29, 2015 and the bid documents were broadcasted to contractors and builders exchanges through FHDA’s Purchasing web page.  A mandatory bid walk was held on January 6, 2016, and a total of five (5) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on February 10, 2016 in the Purchasing Services office.  Four (4) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
TOTAL BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT INCLUDES ALLOWANCE #1 FOR $15,000 
Roofing Constructors Inc. 
DBA: Western Roofing Services 
$347,585
Best Contracting Services, Inc
$435,000
Andy’s Roofing Co., Inc.
$478,641
Stronger Building Services
$516,230
	 
On June 16, 2014, the apparent low bidder Roofing Constructors Inc. DBA: Western Roofing Services sent a letter to the District asking to be relieved of its bid due to a clerical error in preparing its bid price.  Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 5103, the Board of Trustees may grant relief to a bidder who claims a mistake within the 5 day written notice period provided that the mistake makes the bid materially different than what it was intended it to be, and that the mistake was made in filling out the bid and not due to error in judgment or to carelessness in inspecting the site of the work, or in reading the plans or specifications (see attached letter).  
	 
Therefore, Best Contracting Services, Inc, is the apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder.  Furthermore, Best Contracting Services, Inc, and its subcontractors have signed the Appendix A, “Agreement To Be Bound,” and Appendix C, “Agreement of Contractors,” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council. 
	 
Best Contracting Services, Inc. has completed Bid #1120, Building 5100 Roof Replacement at Foothill College; and Project 236E: L2, L3 & L6 Roof Repairs and Project 236F: S4, S5, & L5 Roofing Repairs at De Anza College. 
	 
This project is funded by Measure C and Physical Plant Block Grant (State Scheduled Maintenance) fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to relieve Roofing Constructors Inc. DBA: Western Roofing Services of its bid due to a clerical error in accordance with PCC 5103, and award a contract pursuant to Bid #1749-105, Bldg. 5400 Roof Replacement in the amount of $435,000 to Best Contracting Services, Inc.
